abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the Health
            Sector Support Project for Guinea was judged to be
            moderately satisfactory.  The Bank and borrower performance
            were moderately satisfactory. The risk to development
            outcome was high. Significant changes included restructuring
            of the project, and amending the Development Credit
            Agreement to: (i) eliminate counterpart financing  and
            reallocate the proceeds; and (ii) revise the closing date of
            the project.  Several lessons were learned. Project design
            must balance a range of considerations. These include the
            desired outcomes, the financing instrument, and the
            implementation arrangements. Risk assessment is an essential
            aspect of project design. While overall risk was rated as
            high, the components of this rating were underestimated and
            the mitigation measures were insufficient. Where ministry
            leadership is inadequate, other champions must be found to
            advance the project's objectives. The Bank's
            comparative advantages need to be recognized and exploited.
            There is a need to temper expectations that a single health
            project can impact the entire health sector. While a single
            project financed by the Bank may be a necessary condition
            for sectoral change, it is not sufficient without greater
            political leadership and financial commitment from the
            Guinean authorities. Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) can
            be improved throughout the project. Though the general
            prescription is that M&E systems, including arrangements
            for collecting and analyzing data, should be established
            prior to project launch, Guinea shows that projects can
            recover from inadequate M&E design and early
            implementation weaknesses.

17922748.theme: Population and reproductive health,Health system performance,Child health

repnme.cdata!: Guinea - Health Sector Support Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Health Sector
            Support Project for Guinea is to help decrease maternal and
            infant mortality rates by: (a) avoiding the death of at
            least 12,000 pregnant women, and (b) avoiding the death of
            27,500 children. The reallocation is necessary to finance
            additional training following the cancellation of the
            acquisition of equipment for the planned reproductive health
            training and research center since its construction has been
            suspended by the authorities following issues with
            construction contracts. Therefore, the center will not be
            completed before the end of the project. Since the center
            was to train midwives, it was agreed with the Government to
            use the funds initially allocated for the equipment of the
            center (SDR2.5 million) to training activities for nurses in
            obstetrics and goods and services. In addition to the
            Bank's agreement to the reallocation, government will
            be informed that the project is eligible to the standard
            4-month disbursement grace period, which for the project
            will be from January 1, 2014 to April 30, 2014.

15571033.theme: Population and reproductive health,Health system performance,Child health

repnme.cdata!: Guinea - Health Sector Support Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Health Sector
            Support Project for Guinea is to help decrease maternal and
            infant mortality rates by: (a) avoiding the death of at
            least 12,000 pregnant women, and (b) avoiding the death of
            27,500 children. The changes are as follows: (i) a revision
            of Project Development Objectives (PDOs) and related
            indicators; (ii) a streamlining of project activities; (iii)
            a revision of institutional arrangements; (iv) a
            reallocation of credit proceeds; and (v) an extension of the
            closing date. The expected outcome of the restructuring will
            be a more effective project implementation resulting in an
            improvement in mother and child health services in the 18
            poorest districts of Guinea and 16 health centers in the
            poorest peri-urban areas of Conakry, leading eventually to
            reductions in maternal and child mortality and improvements
            in health status.

repnme.cdata!: Guinea - Health Sector Support Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Health Sector
            Support Project for Guinea is to help decrease maternal and
            infant mortality rates by: (a) avoiding the death of at
            least 12,000 pregnant women, and (b) avoiding the death of
            27,500 children. This extension is needed to provide
            sufficient time for the task team to finalize a level 1
            restructuring with the Government.  The changes which will
            be included in this restructuring are as follows: (i) a
            revision of Project Development Objectives (PDOs) and
            related indicators; (ii) a streamlining of project
            activities; (iii) a revision of institutional arrangements;
            (iv) a reallocation of credit proceeds; and (v) a further
            extension of the closing date to December 31, 2013.  The
            short extension in the closing date requested in this paper
            will allow this process to continue and the restructuring
            package to be finalized.
